data.text: Contents
Introduction

Closed circuit television (CCTV) can be used to monitor a wide variety of locations and aid the deterrence of crime and other incidents. CCTV has become part of modern life and is an expected feature in public buildings and areas. The primary purpose of CCTV at Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (the Trust) is to protect patients, visitors, staff and trust property, by providing a visible deterrent and culture coherent with CCTV operations and by providing recorded images for later analysis with the option of active monitoring.

CCTV systems must comply with regulatory requirements including the Data Protection Act 2018, Freedom of Information Act 2000, the Private Security Industry Act 2001, Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000, the Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984, and guidance from the Information Commissioners Office Services and the Home Office. This policy will make clear the relevance of this guidance and legislation and the responsibilities of the Organisation and Individuals with compliance.
This policy will regulate the management, operation and use of the CCTV system installed at the Trust.
The system comprises a complex system of data networks, storage and control devices, cameras and equipment for the monitoring and review of recorded matter whether used or not.
Scope
The Aim of this policy is to ensure the Trust's compliance with the relevant legislation and guidance appropriate to the use and management of a CCTV system in a public place.

The Policy Objective is to enable the CCTV system at the Trust to be effectively used to protect Patients, Visitors, Staff and Trust Property and contribute to the reduction of crime while complying with relevant legislation, guidance and recommendations.
In pursuit of this the Trust will:
Visibly operate a CCTV System for recording images of activity of persons, vehicles and goods in designated public areas of the site.
Where required or necessary provide to any persons lawfully entitled copies of images captured and recorded by CCTV.
Maintain, update and develop the CCTV System in line with its intended operation.
Ensure that the appropriate legislation, guidance and recommendations are adhered to.
Ensure that management of the CCTV System protects recorded matter, networks and integrity from abuse and unauthorized access consistent with legislation, guidance and recommendations.
Work in partnership with other authorities including the Police to detect and deter crime.
Provide sufficient and appropriate investment to ensure that CCTV remains an effective, useful and functional part of the strategy protecting Patients, Visitors, Staff and Trust Property.
Definitions

table_items.text: ‘CCTV System' means the equipment, recording devices, network devices, cameras, wiring and other components assembled to provide the CCTV service. The CCTV System has a Primary Purpose declared at commissioning which informs this policy and the operation of the system.

CCTV Operator is the person who is using the CCTV system to view live or recorded images and falls into one of two categories under the: ‘Dedicated Operator' means an individual employed for the purpose of Monitoring live CCTV images who takes actions as events occur, who is likely to be a member of the Security Personnel; ‘Casual Operator' means an individual who incidentally monitors CCTV images as part of a role not wholly or partly as a member of the Security Personnel.

Surveillance means any operation where CCTV images are viewed live or recorded for any purpose. An SIA Licence is required when manned guarding activities are undertaken by Contractor Staff involving the use of CCTV equipment to monitor the activities of a member of the public in a public or private place or to identify a particular person other than when protecting property or identifying a trespasser as a Dedicated Operator; An SIA Licence is not required when CCTV operations are carried out as a Casual User or a Dedicated User who is employed by the Trust as Establishment Staff.
‘Sound' means any sound detected, transmitted or stored by the CCTV System.
‘Public Display' means any screen display capable of showing CCTV images which members of the public may see or have access to.

‘ANPR' or Automatic Number Plate Recognition means any system, connected to the CCTV System, or standalone, capable of interpreting Registration Plates of Vehicles from images and processing that data.
‘Recorded Image' means any image whether moving or not that is stored on any media from any source connected to the CCTV System.
‘Redaction' means the process of rendering parts of a Recorded Image unrecognizable.
‘Disclosure' means the supply of any CCTV images to any person other than the Operator including the viewing of live or recorded images in any format.
‘Watermark' refers to the feature employed by the CCTV System which enables detection of tampering with evidential quality CCTV Images.
‘Time Stamp' refers to the date and time annotations included in all CCTV live or Recorded Images.
‘Exported Image' means any Recorded Image transferred from the CCTV System to any other media.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Chief Executive has overall responsibility for the CCTV System at the Trust including its use and operation. This authority is delegated to the CCTV Group chaired by the Head of Security.
The Senior Director of Estates and Facilities is responsible for fully implementing

this policy and any resulting procedures on premises owned by or occupied by the Trust. The Senior Director of Estates and Facilities or their nominated deputy can Disclose Recorded Images onto other media from the CCTV System with the appropriately authorised CCTV Disclosure Form.
The Head of Security has a delegated responsibility for the strategic and

operational management of the CCTV system at. The Head of Security or their nominated deputy can Disclose Recorded Images onto other media from the CCTV System with the appropriately authorized CCTV form.
Designated Contractor is responsible for provision and maintenance of the CCTV system under the advice and direction of the Head of Security.

The Head of Information Governance has responsibility for ensuring that the CCTV system at the Trust operates within the requirements of the Data Protection Act 2018, the Freedom of Information Act 2000, Trust Policy on Data Protection and Trust Policy on Information Governance. The Information Governance Manager is responsible for maintaining the Trust's registration with the Information Commissioner's Office on the existence of the CCTV System at the Trust.

Dedicated Operators operate the CCTV system at the Trust premises in accordance with this policy and have a responsibility to ensure that any licensing requirements are met in relation to the Security Industry Authority.
Casual Operators may as an incidental part of their employed role operate the CCTV system in accordance with this policy.

Security and Car Parking Staff use CCTV system as a tool in the execution of their duties on Trust premises. At any time when using the system for any purpose, they are responsible for that use as governed by this policy. They are responsible for ensuring they are licensed appropriately, if applicable, and that they are sufficiently trained to operate and use the CCTV System. SIA Licensing is not required for this role for establishment staff at the Trust, but is required for any Contract Security Operatives.
Operating the CCTV system

The Operation of the CCTV system is key to its success in achieving its objectives. The environment in which CCTV is operated will be secure and private so that unauthorised/unlicensed personnel cannot access images either live or recorded. The exception to this are monitors in Public areas.

The Trust will ensure that there is effective CCTV coverage in high risk and specialist areas (i.e. Mortuary) in line with specialist services and regulatory guidance and requirements. The CCTV data may be reviewed on a regular basis in line with such guidance.
The Trust display CCTV Privacy Notices in a visible manner and ensure that the notices include information about the use of CCTV.

The CCTV system is based on Internet Protocol (IP) technology, but some legacy systems still use analogue cameras and infrastructure. As such the system may be operated from various locations within the Trust. All areas where CCTV Images can be observed will comply with 7.1 below including activities associated with development and maintenance of the system.
Operation of the CCTV system falls into five categories:

Observation of live images by Dedicated or Casual Operators. Users will observe and act directly on surveillance in real time, taking an appropriate course of action to events as they occur. Observation may be in response to reported acts but not relating to specific or known individuals;

Observation of recorded images by Dedicated or Casual Operators. This will be the observation after the event of images recorded and stored in the CCTV System for forensic purposes. Such images may be recorded to other media for analysis;

Covert surveillance of specific or known individuals invokes the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000 and requires specific authority in order to comply before any surveillance is carried out. This will dealt with by the Police or the Trust with appropriate court authorisation.

Other circumstances where covert use of CCTV could be used is covered under ‘Using Surveillance' (CQC). This covers the use of CCTV for monitoring people in receipt of Health and Social Care services to ensure safety and quality of care. Such use would require approval from the Chief Executive prior to any surveillance.

Public Displays are screens displaying live images from cameras in the immediate location of the screen. They are permitted to reassure the public of the existence of an effective CCTV system, and to deter crime.

The CCTV System allows for sophisticated searches of recorded events, the subsequent storage of images and export to other media formats including MPEG, DVD and photograph. Use of the system is restricted to its purpose of protecting Patients, Visitors, Staff and Trust Property.

The CCTV System uses a range of camera types with differing features, resolution and movement capabilities. Where camera movement is controllable by the CCTV Operator, regard for privacy must be maintained and inappropriate camera aiming where an individual or group of individuals personal privacy is compromised, otherwise may lead to the operator becoming subject to the Trust's Disciplinary Procedure.

Cameras capable of being moved by the CCTV Operator may deploy ‘masking technology' to mask private areas of view. Where these are required, the Head of Security must be consulted to arrange their deployment. Camera positioning will be such that any invasion of privacy is minimised or eliminated with appropriate reassuring measures taken such as physical camera shielding.
Sound
Sound will not be recorded by the main CCTV system, but may be recorded by Body Worn CCTV equipment.
Disclosure of CCTV images
For Disclosure of images including Recorded Images must be consistent with the requirements of the Data Protection Act 2018 and the Freedom of Information Act 2000.
Images can be used by Security and Car Parking Staff to monitor live events, review recent events and search for previous specific events held by the CCTV system:
Any viewing console can display live images. Appropriate passwords will need to be entered to view live images;
A review of events is possible using the console controls to rewind, pause and alter the speed of Recorded Images.

The Export of Images is possible on certain designated consoles with appropriate password protection. No attempt should be made to export Recorded Images from an un-designated console. Any such export is designated as a Disclosure under this policy.
Disclosure of Images can occur in three circumstances:

Disclosed Images are likely to be required after an Incident Report and subsequent review of the CCTV Recorded Images by the Security and Car Parking Staff before export to external media. Before any images are disclosed onto any external media, the CCTV Authorisation Form must be filled in and approved. For prevention and detection of crime, and reasons related to Schedule 11 of the Data Protection Act 2018 approval will be granted by the Head of Security, or the delegated responsible officer for CCTV Disclosures, or nominated Trust Director/General Manager on call. The CCTV Authorisation Form is included in the Appendices.

Disclosure for CCTV images to be used for internal use, such as by Human Resources who may require evidence for disciplinary issues, approval can only be granted by the Head of Information Governance, or their designated deputy, who has overall responsibility for security of data;

For all other reasons including Subject Access Requests disclosures will only occur in response to a formal request and will be determined on a case by case basis. The formal request may be made to any member of Trust staff and each request will be recorded as Access to the CCTV System is restricted, a DVD disc will be prepared by the Security Department ready for
disclosure. Any media onto which CCTV Recorded Images are stored must be kept securely and handled in a manner consistent with the requirements of the Data Protection Act
Recorded Images can be exported in several formats and depending upon need will be:

DVD: Recorded Images must be exported so that images are appropriately equipped with review software, and are of evidential quality including Watermark and Time Stamp. A receipt for the copy requested will be obtained and the requirements of the Data Protection Act 2018 communicated to its recipient. Any evidence disclosed to the Police will be retained and destroyed by the Police in line with relevant legislation and evidential standards. DVDs must be password protected to minimise unauthorised access.

For larger disclosures an encrypted/password protected USB drive may be used to store and disclose CCTV Recorded Images. This should be provided by the requesting party or cost recovered for any devices purchased by the Trust.
All images disclosed under this policy will have been subjected to Redaction where required or possible. The purpose of Redaction is to remove any identifiable characteristics of third parties.
Freedom of Information (FOI) Requests in relation to CCTV Recorded Images should be referred through the Trust's normal route for FOI Requests.
Any Public Displays must only be capable of displaying live images of adjacent cameras.
Retention of CCTV images

It is normal practice for CCTV Systems to overwrite stored images after a set period. Recorded Images held on this CCTV System will be kept for a period between  and 50 days, depending on the system capability. The target system capability should be increased to store the CCTV footage for 90 days.
All Exported Images must be kept in line with the requirements of the Data Protection Act 2018 and disposed of securely when no longer required.
Protection of the CCTV system
The CCTV System operated by the Trust comprises the following:
Individual Cameras capable of independently storing images consistent with their configuration; for Internet Protocol (IP) cameras
An Ethernet network;
Secure Data Switches;
Corporate data switches;
A fibre network;
Digital video recorders – window based servers;
PC viewing stations
The Ethernet and fibre networks operating the CCTV system are part of IT Trust network.
Configuration of the CCTV System is key to its security and the system operates several security measures:
Physical access to the CCTV System is controlled by keys to equipment cabinets and is, with the exception of the Cameras, located in restricted areas;

The CCTV Images are stored via RAID 5 Windows based servers and are overwritten automatically after a specified retention period. Where Digital Video Recorders (DVR) are used, the above applies and admin level access is needed to format the devices.

Access to the network is protected by password, features and functions of the CCTV System are protected by differing levels of password control preventing unauthorised access to Recorded Images and other data;

The CCTV System employs Closed IP Technology and electronically prevents any other components from being connected to the system. The CCTV System will be permanently locked and Unlocking requires authorisation from the Head of Security together with the appropriate passwords.
System Integrity is maintained by use of the following:
Water Mark Technology, where all disclosed images are electronically watermarked to make image tampering detectable for evidence certainty.
The use of an accurate central GPS clock. All equipment including the cameras, reference their internal clocks to the central clock which has a published accuracy of 400 microseconds.

Any person engaged in unauthorised use, tampering, connection, movement, disconnection, or any act that may jeopardise the operation, safety or security of the CCTV System will be subject the Trust's Disciplinary Procedure.
Procedure
Viewing of the Trust CCTV system is restricted to authorised personnel only:
Trust security and Car Parking Officers
Trust security management team
Police Officers investigating an incident.
Internal investigation team for the purpose of a disciplinary investigation.
Out of hours the duty site practitioner, senior manager on-call/ director on-call, may be granted temporary access, but are not authorised to download footage.
Security and Car Parking Officers are authorised to monitor and review CCTV footage whilst carrying out their duties for example but not exclusive.
When in receipt of information relating to a security breach
when in receipt of information relating to a missing patients
when in receipt of information relating to a theft
when in receipt of information relating to an assault
when in receipt of information relating to an infant abduction
when investigating suspicious person/persons
traffic incidents
traffic congestion
security of premises
visitors, patients, staff safety
during a fire call
during a major incident alert
10.1.1 Officers are reminded not to view images of a personal nature or for personal reasons.

10.1.2 Officers are reminded that all images produced by the Trust CCTV system to include body worn footage are protected by the Data Protection Act 2018 and should not be duplicated or discussed with any unauthorised Person/Persons unless otherwise instructed by the Department manager.
10.1.3 Officers are reminded not to discuss actual locations of CCTV cameras with any unauthorised person/persons unless otherwise instructed by the Department manager.

10.1.4 All officers are reminded that all visitors when entering/exiting the security/car parking offices, where CCTV monitoring occurs, must without exception sign and complete in full The Security Offices Entry Log Sheet.
Request for footage from CCTV

When in receipt of a request for Trust CCTV footage, including Body Worn Camera footage, officers are required to complete the appropriate CCTV Disclosure Form, which are located within the Security and Car Parking offices.
10.2.1 The person/organisation requesting CCTV or body worn camera footage will fall into one of two categories:
Police and law enforcement agencies
General public/non- law enforcement agencies
10.2.2 All request forms must be sequentially numbered for audit purpose if a mistake is made please cross through and mark cancelled the team leader/manager is to be notified within 24hours.
10.2.3 Once completed the form is to be handed to the department manager or in their absence a dedicated deputy within 24hours to verify and sign to authorise downloading.

10.2.4 Out of hours when a requested form is completed an e-mail is to be sent to the department manager ensuring alerting them that a request has been made so that action can be taken within 24hours.
10.2.5 All completed forms are to be returned to the Department manager.

10.2.6 In the event that no forms are available or information is being requested re the CCTV system including Body worn camera and or actual camera locations, please ask the person for their name and contact details, ensuring that you give the line manager's details which are as follows:
Basildon Hospital:
Security and Car Park Manager 01268 524900 ext. 8669
Southend Hospital:
Security and Car Parking Manager Tel.01702435555 ext. 5498
Broomfield Hospital:
Car Park and Security Manager Tel: 01245 516191 ext. 6191
If not available, escalate to Trust Head of Security: Facilities and Estates Directorate
Email: ariel.kowalaszek@nhs.net
At no time should officers disclose that footage has been captured, unless to Law enforcement officers or under management instructions.
Body worn cameras
Security and Car Parking Officers are to wear Body Worn Cameras at all times whilst on duty.
10.3.1 Cameras are to be used in all situations when Verbal Abuse, Physical Abuse, or any situation where it may be useful to gather evidence for later use, e.g. Theft, Criminal Damage etc.
10.3.2 The Trust will ensure it is compliant with any regulatory requirements pertaining to the Body Worn Video.

10.3.3 All officers are reminded that when activating the Body Camera a verbal message must be given to the person/person's concerned to warn them that you are going to use the camera to record/ take a picture or record audio. This message is to consist of but not necessarily be limited to the following:
Due to your behaviour I must inform you that I am activating my CCTV camera, which may be used as evidence.

10.3.4 Officers are reminded that when using the body worn camera, or indeed Trust CCTV system during a security incident, reference of which system was used, and all relevant details must be noted within the officers personal notebooks, security log forms, and DATIX, to ensure that evidence can easily be identified.

10.3.5 When the Body Worn CCTV Cameras have been used during an incident, the Security Management Staff must review the CCTV footage to ascertain whether further action or investigation is required. This may accompany a Datix report submitted by the Security Officer regarding the incident.
10.3.6 Officers are required to change batteries/charge the devices every 6 Hours, so that the camera remains operational at all times.
10.3.7 In the event of damage occurring to the Body worn cameras officers are requested to inform the security manager as soon as possible, without exception.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Health and Safety Management Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policy and procedure guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Health and Safety Management Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
